key_points: Hurricane Ida caused extensive flooding and damage, trapping residents and devastating the power grid in Louisiana.
More than 1 million homes and businesses in Louisiana and Mississippi were left without power.
Officials warned power grid repairs could take weeks; damage deemed 'catastrophic'.
President Joe Biden met with Louisiana and Mississippi governors to discuss federal assistance.
FEMA deployed over 3,600 employees and provided supplies in anticipation of the storm.
At least two deaths have been attributed to the storm, with more expected as the full extent of damage is assessed.
Rescue operations saved at least 671 people by Monday afternoon.
New Orleans escaped the catastrophic flooding feared, but faced power outages and a lack of fuel.
COVID-19 concerns rise as evacuees are sheltered; officials aim to move people to hotels for better distancing.
Entergy, the power company, reported extensive damage to transmission lines and substations, with utility workers mobilizing for repairs.
spokespersons: Christina Stephens (Spokesperson, Governor John Bel Edwards)
Collin Arnold (Chief of Emergency Preparedness, New Orleans)
